page.title: 02 CHARLECOTE
page.content:
In the original Domesday Book, Charlecote was in the Tremlau Hundred, which was part of the land of the Count of Meulan. The village was given to Thurstane de Cherlecote by Henry de Montfort, who came over with William the Conqueror. The Book said "Saxi held it, as a free man;3 hides, land for five ploughs, seven slaves, fourteen villagers and two smallholders. Two mills at 21s. Meadow 5 acres." The name (Anglo-Saxon CEORL,COT(E)) means cottage(s) of the churls.In 1086 it was Cerlecote,1123 Cherlcota, 1217 Sherlecote, in 1228 Cherescote, finishing with its present spelling in 1484.
(Charlecote Park,Charlecote House)
